person_810.name: Alexander III
person_810.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

person_991.name: Athenaeus
person_991.description: Athenaeus of Naucratis was a Greek rhetorician and grammarian, who lived sometime around the end of the 2nd and beginning of the 3rd century AD.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_057.name: John BakerHolroyd
person_057.description: Independent-minded MP; from 1802 1st Baron Sheffield and from 1816 1st Earl of Sheffield. President of the Board of Agriculture, 1802-1806. During autumn 1803 Davy stayed with him for three weeks at his Sussex seat, Sheffield Place. FRSL.

person_288.name: ThomasBernard
person_288.description: Philantropist and a founding member of the Royal Institution serving as an early Treasurer. Later influential in running the institution, especially its lecture programme.

person_993.name: JohnRickman
person_993.description: FRS, a civil servant and statistician. He was a close friend of Robert Southey.

person_992.name: SamuelBoddington
person_992.description: Member of Parliament for Tralee in 1807 with a large estate in the West Indies. In February 1804, he gave the Institution a mineral collection which Davy valued at £150.

person_210.name: WilliamBabington
person_210.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

person_997.name: ThomasDouglas
person_997.description: Lord Selkirk was Thomas Douglas, from 1799, 5th Earl of Selkirk (1771-1820), an Annual Subscriber to the Royal Institution and involved with the Board of Agriculture. He was heavily involved in the Highland clearances moving people to Canada. FRSL from 1808.

person_998.name: HowePeter Browne
person_998.description: The Earl of Altamont was the courtesy title of Howe Peter Browne, from 1809 2nd Marquis of Sligo, He was an Annual Subscriber to the Royal Institution and (much) later Governor of Jamacia.

person_999.name: MaryHill
person_999.description: Lady Downshire was Mary Hill, nee Sandys, Marchioness of Downshire and later a Baroness in her own right. Her husband Arthur Hill, 2nd Marquess of Downshire, was involved in the Board of Agriculture.

person_329.name: Thomas (Tom)Wedgwood
person_329.description: Youngest son of Josiah Wedgwood who became a close friend of Davy's. Together they published a paper which has been taken as marking the start of chemical photography.

person_163.name: Thomas CharlesHope
person_163.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_558.name: GraceDavy
person_558.description: Davy's mother who spent her entire life in West Cornwall.

person_002.name: AnnaBeddoes
person_002.description: Anna Beddoes, née Edgeworth, the wife of Thomas Beddoes who befriended Davy when he arrived in Bristol. Critics have speculated that they had an affair because Davy wrote poems to Anna and she wrote poems for him that he copied out in his notebooks.

person_990.name: CrippsJohn Martyn
person_990.description: Sussex landowner, annual subscriber to the RI and honorary member of the Board of Agriculture.

person_994.name: MarthaAllen
person_994.description: Arthur Young's wife and Charles Burney's sister-in-law. Her marriage was apparently unhappy. She was the the great-grand-daughter of John Allen, and daughter of Alderman Allen, of Lyng House in the county of Norfolk. Her mother was Mary Maxey, (c.1705-1776).

person_346.name: JohnEgerton
person_346.description: MP for Chester and from 1814 8th baronet. Landowner who found a vein of copper ore on his land and who asked Davy for advice.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_865.name: Heraclitus
person_865.description: An ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from the city of Ephesus, which was then part of the Persian Empire.

person_1004.name: GeorgeMillet
person_1004.description: East India Company Captain who was in charge of the Hindostan on its return voyage from China in 1802. It is likely that he's related to Davy's family on his mother's side (also called Millet).

person_387.name: John JoachimBecher
person_387.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_1005.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
person_1005.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

person_519.name: WilliamWhiston
person_519.description: English (unorthodox) theologian, historian, natural philosopher, and mathematician. A leading figure in promoting the ideas of Isaac Newton whom he succeeded as Lucasian Professor.

person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_877.name: Marcus TuilliusCicero
person_877.description: a Roman statesman, lawyer, scholar, philosopher, writer and Academic skeptic

person_995.name: Françoisde La Mothe Le Vayer
person_995.description: a French philosopher, philologist and historian

person_031.name: JohnMilton
person_031.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

person_1022.name: BoyleRoche
person_1022.description: Irish politician most remembered for getting his metaphors mixed up.

person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

person_1006.name: MargaretBeaumont
person_1006.description: Wife of Sir George Howland Beaumont, patron of the arts and friend of the Wordsworths. She was the daughter of the MP, John Willes, and lived at Coleorton Hall from around 1800 after living at 34 Grosvenor Square, London.

person_011.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
person_011.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

person_236.name: WilliamNicholson
person_236.description: Founding editor of A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts (1797-1814) where Davy published some of his early papers. Part of the Godwin circle.

person_1010.name: JohnAikin
person_1010.description: the brother of poet Anna Barbauld, Aikin was a medical doctor who stopped practising in 1798 to focus instead on his writing.

person_333.name: EdwardGibbon
person_333.description: English essayist, historian, and politician. FRSL.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_1007.name: FrancesVaillant
person_1007.description: Miss Vaillant is mentioned as a subscriber to the Royal Institution in 1805; she lived on Piccadilly. See the appendix of Hattie Lloyd's PhD, 'Rulers of Opinion: Women at the Royal Institution of Great Britain, 1799-1812', submitted to UCL, 2018 (p. 317)

place_1234.name: Charing Cross
place_1234.description: a junction in Westminster, London, England, where six routes meet.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_914.name: River Severn
place_914.description: At 220 miles long, the longest river in Great Britain.

place_605.name: River Avon
place_605.description: The River Avon in central England flows generally south-westwards and is a major left-bank tributary of the River Severn.

place_873.name: Iran
place_873.description: Iran, also known as Persia and officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country located at the crossroads of West, Central and South Asia.

place_509.name: Lizard Point
place_509.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

place_294.name: Bagshot Heath
place_294.description: An area of wet and dry heath, bog, and unimproved grassland in Surrey, England.

place_1230.name: Iona
place_1230.description: an island in the Inner Hebrides, off the Ross of Mull on the western coast of Scotland.

place_083.name: Matlock, Derbyshire
place_083.description: Matlock is a town in Derbyshire.

place_288.name: Doncaster
place_288.description: A city in South Yorkshire, England.

place_569.name: Sicily
place_569.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

otherwork_289.author: François de La Mothe Le Vayer
